We have just reÂ­leased Vert.x 3.5.1!

Fixes first!

As usual this reÂ­lease fixes bugs reÂ­ported in 3.5.0, see the reÂ­lease notes.

JUnit 5 support

This reÂ­lease inÂ­troÂ­duces the new vertx-â€‹junit5 modÂ­ule.

JUnit 5 is a rewrite of the faÂ­mous Java testÂ­ing frameÂ­work that brings new inÂ­terÂ­estÂ­ing feaÂ­tures, inÂ­cludÂ­ing:

  • nested tests,
  • the abilÂ­ity to give a human-â€‹readable deÂ­scripÂ­tion of tests and test cases (and yes, even use emoÂ­jis),
  • a modÂ­uÂ­lar exÂ­tenÂ­sion mechÂ­aÂ­nism that is more powÂ­erÂ­ful than the JUnit 4 runÂ­ner mechÂ­aÂ­nism (@RunÂ­With anÂ­noÂ­taÂ­tion),
  • conÂ­diÂ­tional test exÂ­eÂ­cuÂ­tion,
  • paÂ­raÂ­meÂ­terÂ­ized tests, inÂ­cludÂ­ing from sources such as CSV data,
  • the supÂ­port of Java 8 lambda exÂ­presÂ­sions in the reÂ­worked built-â€‹in asÂ­serÂ­tions API,
  • supÂ­port for runÂ­ning tests preÂ­viÂ­ously writÂ­ten for JUnit 4.

SupÂ­pose that we have a SampleVerticle verÂ­tiÂ­cle that exÂ­poses a HTTP server on port 11981. Here is how we can test its deÂ­ployÂ­ment as well as the reÂ­sult of 10 conÂ­curÂ­rent HTTP reÂ­quests:

@Test
@DisplayName("ğŸš€ Deploy a HTTP service verticle and make 10 requests")
void useSampleVerticle(Vertx vertx, VertxTestContext testContext) {
  WebClient webClient = WebClient.create(vertx);
  Checkpoint deploymentCheckpoint = testContext.checkpoint();

  Checkpoint requestCheckpoint = testContext.checkpoint(10);
  vertx.deployVerticle(new SampleVerticle(), testContext.succeeding(id -> {
    deploymentCheckpoint.flag();

    for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
      webClient.get(11981, "localhost", "/")
        .as(BodyCodec.string())
        .send(testContext.succeeding(resp -> {
          testContext.verify(() -> {
            assertThat(resp.statusCode()).isEqualTo(200);
            assertThat(resp.body()).contains("Yo!");
            requestCheckpoint.flag();
          });
        }));
    }
  }));
}

The test method above benÂ­eÂ­fits from the inÂ­jecÂ­tion of a workÂ­ing Vertx conÂ­text, a VertxTestContext for dealÂ­ing with asynÂ­chroÂ­nous opÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tions, and the guarÂ­anÂ­tee that the exÂ­eÂ­cuÂ­tion time is bound by a timeÂ­out which can opÂ­tionÂ­ally be conÂ­figÂ­ured using a @Timeout anÂ­noÂ­taÂ­tion.

The test sucÂ­ceeds when all checkÂ­points have been flagged. Note that vertx-junit5 is agÂ­nosÂ­tic of the asÂ­serÂ­tions liÂ­brary being used: you may opt for the built-â€‹in JUnit 5 asÂ­serÂ­tions or use a 3rd-â€‹party liÂ­brary such as AsÂ­sertJ as we did in the exÂ­amÂ­ple above.

You can checkÂ­out the source on GitHub, read the manÂ­ual and learn from the exÂ­amÂ­ples.

Web API Contract enhancements

The packÂ­age vertx-web-api-contract inÂ­cludes a vaÂ­riÂ­ety of fixes, from schema $ref to reÂ­vamped docÂ­uÂ­menÂ­taÂ­tion. You can give a look at list of all fixes/imÂ­proveÂ­ments here and all breakÂ­ing changes here.

From 3.5.1 to load the opeÂ­napi spec and inÂ­stanÂ­tiÂ­ate the Router you should use new method OpenAPI3RouterFactory.create() that reÂ­places old methÂ­ods createRouterFactoryFromFile() and createRouterFactoryFromURL(). This new method acÂ­cepts relÂ­aÂ­tive paths, abÂ­solute paths, local URL with file:// and reÂ­mote URL with http://. Note that if you want refeer to a file relÂ­aÂ­tive to your jarâ€™s root, you can simÂ­ply use a relÂ­aÂ­tive path and the parser will look out the jar and into the jar for the spec.

From 3.5.1 all setÂ­tings about OpenAPI3RouterFactory beÂ­havÂ­iours durÂ­ing router genÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion are inÂ­globed in a new obÂ­ject called RouterFactoryOptions. From this obÂ­ject you can:

  • ConÂ­figÂ­ure if you want to mount a deÂ­fault valÂ­iÂ­daÂ­tion failÂ­ure hanÂ­dler and which one (methÂ­ods setMountValidationFailureHandler(boolean) and setValidationFailureHandler(Handler))
  • ConÂ­figÂ­ure if you want to mount a deÂ­fault 501 not imÂ­pleÂ­mented hanÂ­dler and which one (methÂ­ods setMountNotImplementedFailureHandler(boolean) and setNotImplementedFailureHandler(Handler))
  • ConÂ­figÂ­ure if you want to mount ResponseContentTypeHandler auÂ­toÂ­matÂ­iÂ­cally (method setMountResponseContentTypeHandler(boolean))
  • ConÂ­figÂ­ure if you want to fail durÂ­ing router genÂ­erÂ­aÂ­tion when seÂ­cuÂ­rity hanÂ­dlers are not conÂ­figÂ­ured (method setRequireSecurityHandlers(boolean))

After iniÂ­tialÂ­izaÂ­tion of route, you can mount the RouterFactoryOptions obÂ­ject with method routerFactory.setOptions() when you want beÂ­fore callÂ­ing getRouter().

RxJava deprecation removal

It is imÂ­porÂ­tant to know that 3.5.x will be the last reÂ­lease with the legacy xyzObservable() methÂ­ods:

@Deprecated()
public Observable<HttpServer> listenObservable(int port, String host);

has been reÂ­placed since Vert.x 3.4 by:

public Single<HttpServer> rxListen(int port, String host);

The xyzObservable() depÂ­reÂ­cated methÂ­ods will be reÂ­moved in Vert.x 3.6.

Wrap up

Vert.x 3.5.1 reÂ­lease notes and breakÂ­ing changes:

  • https://github.com/vert-â€‹x3/wiki/wiki/3.5.1-â€‹Release-Notes
  • https://github.com/vert-â€‹x3/wiki/wiki/3.5.1-â€‹Breaking-Changes

The event bus client using the SockJS bridge are availÂ­able from NPM, Bower and as a WeÂ­bÂ­Jar:

  • https://www.npmjs.com/packÂ­age/vertx3-â€‹eventbus-client
  • https://github.com/vert-â€‹x3/vertx-â€‹bus-bower
  • http://www.weÂ­bÂ­jars.org/

Docker imÂ­ages are also availÂ­able on the Docker Hub. The Vert.x disÂ­triÂ­bÂ­uÂ­tion is also availÂ­able from SDÂ­KMan and HomeÂ­Brew.

The arÂ­tiÂ­facts have been deÂ­ployed to Maven CenÂ­tral and you can get the disÂ­triÂ­bÂ­uÂ­tion on BinÂ­tray.

Happy codÂ­ing !
